climbs.name: Solar Plexus
climbs.fa: Equipped/FA: Dom Rickicki FFA: Buster Jesik

content.description:
A stickclip is recommended.

This is the furthest right line on the wall that has perma-draws hanging. Begin just left of the first bolt, and climb up and right until you're underneath the steep corner. Climb straight up through the pumpy corner to a ledge and a no hands rest. From here, fire directly up through the crux boulder problem using jams and face holds to the anchor. This has fun climbing on positive holds through steep rock.
content.protection: 7 permas + drop in anchors. First bolt left open for stick clipping.
content.location:
Right of

Pneumothorax

, this climbs through the steep corner feature to a face above.

content.description: Pneumothorax begins with a challenging boulder-problem off the ground before engaging a short splitter hand/finger crack for about 15 feet. Above the crack, Pneumothorax traverses right to a massive undercling, while "Paradoxical Movement" heads left. From the undercling, crank through the steepest part of the wall into a brief boulder problem, then hold on for another 30 feet to the chains.
content.location: It is directly above the largest "belay platform", under the steepest part of the wall.

content.description:
Often associated with a pneumothorax, Paradoxical Movement should not be taken lightly. Manage the impending pump on this continually steep route until you pass the crux and are rewarded with a few bolts of vert climbing on fun patina.

This route climbs mostly larger holds with refreshing movement that sets itself apart from other routes I have done at The Crags. Also, compared to

Pneumothorax

, the crux is significantly easier and has multiple solutions. Because of this, I have a hard time grading it but think it is a solid 5.12.
content.protection:
Clip the first 4 bolts of

Pneumothorax

+ 9 more. This may have permadraws by the Spring of 2022. You can skip a bolt mid-crux safely.
content.location:
See the topo. It is left of

Pneumothorax

.
